entry.title: Finance Connect: Strategic Transformation, Not Just Applications
entry.content:
Hello, SAP Community!

As finance leaders navigate an era where strategic agility isn't just advantageous (it's essential for survival), one statistic stands out: According to Gartner, 62% of CEOs have selected growth as their top business priority for 2024-2025, marking the highest level since 2014.

This surge in focus on growth presents both unprecedented opportunities and fundamental challenges: How do you transform finance from a reactive reporting function into a strategic growth engine that powers real-time decision-making across the enterprise?

For part 3 of this blog series on SAP Connect 2025, I’m sharing my list of must-attend sessions at SAP Finance Connect 2025. These sessions offer not just technological solutions but a strategic framework that aligns financial operations with growth imperatives for finance leaders and finance technology professionals.

If this is the first time you're hearing about SAP Connect 2025, read this blog first.

 

Flourishing Finance Function

Your organization has ambitious growth targets. Your CEO is pushing for expansion into new markets, product innovation, and operational scaling, adding responsibilities beyond finance to the office of CFO. Yet, when it comes to providing the financial processes and insights needed to fuel these initiatives, your finance team is still wrestling with:

  • Fragmented financial data scattered across multiple systems and departments
  • Manual reconciliation processes that delay critical decision-making
  • Disconnected planning cycles that can't adapt quickly to market changes
  • Limited visibility into real-time performance across business units

The path begins with understanding how connected finance can specifically support your organization's growth priorities.

The need to create a connected financial ecosystem that integrates, extends, and automates your finance solutions and processes can be met with SAP Business Technology Platform. SAP BTP will strengthen your existing (and sometimes reactive) finance processes, transforming them into a proactive strategy that enables your finance function to flourish. Check out sap.com/btp-for-finance page for more in-depth information on how SAP BTP helps deliver better and more efficient Finance processes.

Here are my three must-attend sessions at Finance Connect that will expand how you think about finance technology possibilities:

 

Your must-attend sessions at Finance Connect

Scenario 1: Finance Closing

Your challenge: The Finance function needs to take the driver’s seat in leading the organization to be proactive in responding to changing requirements and strategies. But when it comes to financial close, it’s still a chaotic and manual process with many versions of documents and reviews.  Read about the full use case here.

The Solution: Explore Process Automation with SAP Build to streamline repeated processes. Eliminating manual tasks frees up your employees’ time, allowing them to focus on strategy and other important activities.

Business Impact: By automating and streamlining repetitive financial closing processes such as data entry and data collection, invoices can be processed 50% faster, with a 55% faster month-end close time.

If this is you, be sure to add this session to your agenda:

A fast close with SAP Advanced Financial Closing and SAP BTP | FIN1909

Wednesday Oct 8 | 11:15 AM – 12:00 PM PDT

 

Scenario 2: Enterprise Performance Management

Your challenge: Your team hopes to drive coordinated business transformation through enterprise performance management. But with multiple ERP and EPM applications, the execution of holistic performance management still struggles with fragmented systems that prevent effective forecasting and strategic alignment across the enterprise.

The Solution: Enterprise performance management technology should integrate easily with existing systems like financial consolidation and group reporting. Discover how SAP Integration Suite connects enterprise systems to streamline data availability, while SAP Build automates processes, enabling AI to deliver more accurate predictions.

Business Impact: In their session FIN2330, PwC shares how they were able to shorten close cycles and improve data accuracy in enterprise performance management.

If this is you, be sure to add these sessions to your agenda:

The EPM evolution: SAP EPM across the value chain | FIN2152

Tuesday Oct 7 | 11:00 AM – 11:20 AM PDT

Driving Financial Agility — PwC’s In-House EPM Transformation with Group Reporting | FIN2330

Tuesday Oct 7 | 3:15 PM – 4:00 PM PDT

 

 

Register Now: Start Your Strategic Finance Growth Journey

The goal is to create an intelligent financial nervous system that connects every aspect of your financial operations to drive outcomes. With SAP Business Technology Platform, your finance team can transform how your organization thinks, plans, and executes on growth opportunities.

Register now for Finance Connect 2025 to gain invaluable knowledge, discover SAP Business Technology Platform’s finance use cases, and join a community of organizations turning growth ambitions into a connected reality. Take the first steps to transform your financial operations into a strategic transformation advantage.

 

Check out the following blogs for other SAP Connect events:

  • SAP Connect 2025: The Ultimate Business Transformation Experience
  • SAP BTP for HR at SAP Connect and Success Connect 2025 summary
  • Success Connect: Your People Deserve More Than Just Software - They Deserve Success
  • Discover SAP Business Technology Platform at SAP Connect and Spend Connect 2025
  • SAP BTP: Creating Connections at Supply Chain Connect

entry.title: New CI Pipeline Restart Extension features: supporting new Pipeline package and improved Restart Job
entry.content:
We are excited to announce the release of Cloud Integration Pipeline Extension - Restart via Data Store in version 1.0.1.

This update introduces several powerful new features and improvements:

  • Supports new integration packages for the Pipeline for Cloud Integration and allows flexible linkage of Generic Pipeline copies to the Pipeline Stages.
  • Enhanced Restart Job Integration Flow:
    • Generic Job Profile to restart all integration scenarios defined in the Partner Directory through the Pipeline Framework.
    • New configuration options to persist the Job Log.
    • New Integration Flow "Pipeline API - Restart Job Log" to retrieve both the Restart Job run list and detailed log data (if log persistence is enabled).
  • Improved configuration and monitoring: New parameters (such as "NotOlderThanHours" for Restart Job), several bug fixes, enriched monitoring headers, and better exception handling.

With these enhancements, version 1.0.1 delivers more flexibility, transparency, and control when managing restarts in your Cloud Integration pipelines.

Integration Package content

New package consists of six Integration Flows, one central Script Collection and one Value Mapping. 2 new artifacts have been added:

  • Pipeline API – Restart Job Log (Optional). This Integration Flow enables API-based retrieval of stored Job Logs. It is built on top of the standard Message Processing Logs (MPL) API and allows either to retrieve the restart job log or to query MPL details of executed Restart Jobs.
  • Value Mapping to determine Pipeline Stage (Optional). The Data Store Entry Name includes a 2-letter code for the Pipeline Stage, derived from the technical name of Pipeline IFlow where the error occurred. This Value Mapping allows to link custom IFlow copies to their Pipeline Stage.

Support for new Pipeline integration packages

The new Cloud Integration Pipeline packages introduce Integration Flows with updated technical IDs that include the version marker “v2”. To ensure compatibility, these new IFlow IDs have been added to the stage determination logic.

In addition, the latest Pipeline version now propagates the MPL ID of the source Pipeline IFlow to the custom error handling IFlow. This allows the Data Store entry name to be built using the original source MPL ID, rather than the MPL ID of the custom error handling flow (as was the case in version 1 of the Cloud Integration Pipeline package).

Pipeline Stage Determination

Each Data Store entry name includes the mandatory attribute Pipeline Stage, which indicates where the exception occurred. In the new version of the Restart Extension, the pipeline stage is resolved through a two-step process. If neither step succeeds, a default value is assigned: Stage (NA) or "Not Assigned".

  1. Technical ID Prefix Check. The system first evaluates the prefix of the source pipeline Integration Flow’s technical ID. This was the only approach available in version 1.0.0. For example, if you copy a generic Integration Flow to create a receiver-specific outbound pipeline IFlow, the technical ID must start with the correct stage prefix:
    com.sap.integration.cloud.pipeline.v2.generic.step06.outbound.myCustomIFlow is resolved to stage (OB).
  2. Value Mapping Check. If the stage cannot be determined from the prefix, the new version applies a Value Mapping. This mapping links custom IFlow technical IDs to specific pipeline stages, allowing you to flexibly assign non-standard technical IDs to the correct stage (see screenshot).

Generic (Default) Job Profile

In version 1.0.0, the Restart Job IFlow could restart only specific interfaces defined in the Job Profile. One of the most common feedback points was the need for a generic Restart Job, similar to what is available in SAP PO, that could restart all integration scenarios configured for the Cloud Integration Pipeline.

This capability has now been added. With the Generic Restart Job Profile, all scenarios where the Partner ID is determined using the Alternative Partner approach can be restarted in one go. The configuration effort is minimal: the only requirement is that the Job Profile status is set to "active."

Optionally, you can exclude specific integration scenarios from the Generic Restart Job by providing them in the parameter InterfacePidExclusionList.

New Job Profile Parameters

The Restart Job Profile now supports additional optional parameters that extend flexibility and monitoring:

  • NotOlderThanHours. In version 1.0.0, filtering was only possible with the static interval parameters TimeFrom and TimeTo. In the new version, if TimeFrom is not explicitly set, this parameter can dynamically calculate it as: 
TimeFrom = (Job run start timestamp) – (Configured number of hours in NotOlderThanHours)
  • RestartJobLog. By default, the job log is stored only in memory within the message header jobLogHeader (accessible only when Trace is activated). With this parameter, you can define where and how the job log is stored:
    • attach – the job log is attached to the MPL of the Restart Job IFlow, using the Restart Job ID as MPL Attachment name.
    • persist – the job log is persisted in the database using the Persist Message step.
    • custom – the job log is sent via a ProcessDirect extension to a custom-built IFlow. In this case, an additional parameter must be maintained in the Job Profile restartJobLogExitEndpoint with the value of ProcessDirect endpoint.

Pipeline API Operations

A new API Integration Flow Pipeline API – Restart Job Log has been introduced in the latest package version. This Integration Flow enables API-based retrieval of Restart Job Logs, provided that the RestartJobLog parameter of the Job Profile is set to either "attach" or "persist".

The following queries are supported:

  • Retrieve the restart job log for a specific Restart Job instance by supplying either the MPL ID of the Restart Job IFlow or the unique Restart Job ID.
  • Query MPL details of executed Restart Jobs based on selection criteria, in order to obtain the MPL ID of the Restart Job IFlow or the unique Restart Job ID.

For further details, see the updated Configuration Guide included in the package.

entry.title: A Smarter Move from Boomi and MuleSoft to SAP Integration Suite - Assessed, Automated, Validated
entry.content:
We are living in an era of intelligent transformation, a time when the convergence of digital, physical, and biological worlds is reshaping every facet of our existence. Businesses are evolving with almost breathless speed, with enterprises expanding and adopting new applications, systems, and business models. However, this rapid evolution brings forth a surge in complexity, compelling enterprises to modernise their integration landscape in order to simplify connectivity, improve agility, and reduce operational overhead.

Imagine if your systems spoke the same language, data didn’t wait in queues, processes moved with instinct, and not instruction, that’s where SAP Integration Suite takes the lead, not just as a replacement for legacy platforms but as a strategic enabler of digital transformation and landscape consolidation. It silently conducts the symphony weaving APIs, events, processes, and data into a seamless rhythm. Just flowing….

Why Enterprises Are Making the Shift with SAP Integration Suite

Many organisations who started their journey with legacy middleware are now facing:

  • Fragmented integration landscapes across multiple middleware technologies
  • Rising costs associated with platform sprawl
  • Limited visibility and control over end-to-end processes
  • Challenges in scaling integrations across hybrid and multi-cloud environments

SAP Integration Suite provides a compelling alternative offering native integration with SAP and non-SAP systems, support for hybrid and cloud-native scenarios, and a suite of capabilities for API management, event-driven integration, and process orchestration all in one platform. Cohesion becomes essential when the architecture spans multiple middleware solutions. Consolidating your middleware landscape under one middleware platform brings tangible benefits to an enterprise as it reduces total cost of ownership(TCO) through fewer platforms to manage, maintain and operate. In SAP centric environment, moving to SAP Integration Suite has its advantages. However, the path to consolidation isn’t always straightforward, especially if the customer’s landscape has mature middleware platforms like Boomi and MuleSoft.

 Advantages of SAP Integration Suite over Boomi and MuleSoft

  • Smooth Migration from SAP PO/PI
    • SAP Integration Suite: Provides migration automation tool with message mapping automation from SAP PI/PO to SAP IS ensuring smoother transition.
    • MuleSoft/Boomi: No direct migration path, customers must redesign integrations from scratch
  • Pre-Package Integration content
    • SAP Integration Suite: Access to SAP API Business Hub with hundreds of pre-built integration flows (iFlows), APIs, and event packages specifically for SAP business processes.
    • MuleSoft/Boomi: Offer generic templates and accelerators but limited in-depth SAP
  • Native SAP Connectivity
    • SAP Integration Suite: Comes with pre-built adapters and deep integration with SAP applications (S/4HANA, ECC, SuccessFactors, Ariba, Concur, IBP, etc.), ensuring faster implementation and reduced customization.
    • MuleSoft & Boomi: Require third-party connectors or additional customization to integrate seamlessly with SAP landscapes.

Simplifying Migration from MuleSoft and Boomi with an End-to-End Migration Accelerator Tool

To support enterprises who are on a journey to migrate from MuleSoft and Boomi to SAP Integration Suite, we have developed a purpose-crafted accelerator that streamlines the entire lifecycle of migration from MuleSoft and Boomi to SAP Integration Suite. This tool helps assess, automate, validate, and govern migrations at scale reducing manual effort, improving accuracy, and accelerating time to value.

Here’s how it works:

Migration Assessment for MuleSoft & Boomi

  • Analyze's source artifacts (zip/process archives)
  • Identifies APIs, Processes/ Flows, connectors, and backend systems
  • Calculates integration complexity
  • Recommends equivalent SAP adapters
  • Produces a detailed PDF migration report to drive stakeholder alignment

Automated i-Flow Generation

  • Reconstructs source logic into SAP Integration Suite i-Flows
  • Uses pre-built templates for common patterns
  • Offers SAP aligned adapter recommendations through template iflows.
  • Reduces development effort by up to 30%

Mapping Logic Migration

      MuleSoft

  • Parses complex MuleSoft DWL scripts
  • Supports in conversion of DWL to Graphical mapping formats
  • Preserves nested structures and transformation logic
  • Enables plug-and-play use in SAP Integration Suite

      Boomi

  • Conversion of JavaScript to Groovy Script mapping using AI.

Validation & Testing Framework

  • Validation of migrated interfaces.
  • Compares payloads across source and target middleware and flags discrepancies.
  • Reduces test effort significantly.
  • Visual representation of the test results.

Quality Monitoring & Governance Dashboards: enhancing the existing Product monitoring capabilities

  • Provides near real-time visibility into migrated integration flows and API's enhancing the product monitoring capability
  • Customized monitoring alerts and reports of the interfaces based on filters set, through email alerts.
  • Tracks SLA compliance, error trends, and integration health at tenant level
  • AI enabled Error Info chatbot which provides potential causes if error and suggestions  to fix.
  • Version Management dashboard across all tenant in the account.
  • Certificate lifecycle management.
  • Alerting mechanism for failed transactions improving the response time of maintenance and support team.

AI Chatbot for auto documentation of Migration project

  • Generates documents (technical specification, cutover plan etc) associated with migration

So are you ready to modernize Your Middleware Landscape with SAP Integration Suite? Whether you are currently on MuleSoft or Boomi, moving to SAP Integration Suite doesn't have to be daunting. With the right approach and the right tools, you can migrate with confidence, reduce risks, and unlock a future-ready integration landscape with end-to-end automation.

Reach out to learn how we can support your middleware transformation from MuleSoft or Boomi to SAP Integration Suite.

entry.title: Int4 Suite Agents Empowers Functional Consultants To Test Integrated SAP S/4HANA Business Processes
entry.content:
Introduction 

Integrated business processes are the bloodstream of SAP systems. Every Sales Order, Purchase Order, Delivery, and Invoice has to flow smoothly, not just within SAP, but across EDI partners (customer, vendors, 3PL partners) banks, warehouses, tax portals.

Here’s the paradox: SAP S/4HANA projects have plenty of sophisticated automation tools, but they rarely help functional consultants in their manual tests. Instead, those tools get pushed into the narrow niche of automation testers. Functional consultants treat them like mythical dragons, complicated, dangerous, and likely to drag them away from their real work into procedural swamps.

The result? Slow testing cycles, dependency on integration specialists, and endless waiting for external partners to provide messages or confirmations.

Changing the story with simulation agents

The better path is not to force functional consultants into scripting or automation frameworks, but to give them simulation agents that mimic the system environment.

Instead of saying: “learn a test framework and run automated scripts,” we can say: “here are agents that simulate your missing EDI partner, your unavailable 3rd party/legacy system and you can test with them right now.”

This changes the game:

  • No competition with automation teams.
  • No learning curve with complex frameworks and procedural delays.
  • Consultants get something they instantly understand: realistic test conditions on demand, using actual historical production data.

How Int4 Suite Agents Work

With Int4 Suite, simulation agents provide a simple interface: the consultant performs the transaction in SAP, the agent feeds in authentic historical test data, and then automatically checks whether the newly generated EDI or non-EDI message matches what was sent in production.

Below are examples of key agents and how they fit into typical integrated OTC and P2P processes

Figure - meet the Int4 Suite Agents 

EDI Partner Agent (based on historical data)

Role: Replays authentic production EDI messages from trading partners (ORDERS, DESADV, INVOIC).

How it works:

  • Consultant performs the transaction in SAP (e.g., creates delivery, sends invoice).
  • Agent provides historical test data from previously exchanged documents.
  • Agent automatically compares the newly generated EDI message with the production one for a similar case.

OTC examples:

  • Consultant in the OTC team replays historical ORDERS from the largest customer and verifies whether, after pricing condition changes, the system still calculates correctly.
  • Consultant tests goods receipt with historical DESADV data; agent compares the new EDI message against the production one.
  • Consultant issues a sales invoice (INVOIC) and agent validates it against the original production invoice, checking VAT rules.

Figure - Select Historical EDI messages from Production system which need to be rerun on Test System 

P2P examples:

  • Consultant creates a purchase order; agent provides a historical ORDRSP where the supplier delivered partially, then compares the new outbound message.
  • Agent simulates a supplier INVOIC and verifies whether workflows behave the same after configuration changes.

Figure - manipulate the historical/production landscape EDI message data before sending that to the test environment

Unavailable System Agent (Non-SAP)

Role: Simulates external systems (banks, customs, WMS/TMS, tax portals) with historical production communications.

How it works:

  • Consultant runs the business process in SAP.
  • Agent injects historical test data from the external system.
  • Agent compares the new outbound message with the original production one.

OTC examples:

  • Consultant tests e-invoicing using a historically rejected invoice; agent checks whether the new output matches the original and if the new rules handle it.
  • Consultant tests shipment confirmations with historical WMS responses.

P2P examples:

  • Consultant tests bank payments; agent supplies historical payment files and checks the new output structure.
  • Consultant tests tax submissions; agent provides historical records and compares new vs. old messages.

Figure - Display the historical EDI data used on production landscape before rerunning that on the test environment 

Historical Data Agent

Role: The production message librarian, replays large volumes or special cases directly from production.

How it works:

  • Consultant triggers transactions in SAP (bulk orders, invoices, returns).
  • Agent provides the historical payloads.
  • Agent verifies test messages against the production equivalents.

OTC examples:

  • Consultant replays a “Black Friday” scenario with 10,000 ORDERS; agent validates each new EDI message against its production twin.
  • Consultant tests credit memo flows from historical complaint cases.

Figure – run many historical messages on the test environment for bulk testing purposes 

P2P examples:

  • Consultant tests bulk supplier invoices; agent validates the outputs against production.
  • Consultant tests blocked spare-parts orders with historical references.

Integration Consultant Agent

Role: A technical assistant that retrieves and compares messages from middleware layers (PI/PO, CPI).

How it works:

  • Consultant executes the business process in SAP.
  • Agent fetches the historical integration payload.
  • Agent highlights differences between new and historical messages.

OTC examples:

  • Consultant creates a sales order; agent compares the IDoc/XML message with the historical SAP Integration Suite payload.
  • Agent highlights mapping differences at field level after configuration changes.

Figure – fetch an EDI payload produced by the integration platform (SAP Integration Suite, etc.) from a newly created business document and compare with the historical one from the production landscape without asking SAP Integration Consultant for help 

P2P examples:

  • Consultant enters a supplier invoice; agent pulls historical Ariba-CPI payload and checks consistency.
  • Agent validates purchase order messages across production and test runs.

Why it matters for SAP S/4HANA projects

In S/4HANA transformations, the external world doesn’t care about your internal redesigns. Customers, suppliers, and banks still expect exactly the same messages they used to get. Outbound and inbound interfaces are fragile bridges that must remain stable.

By equipping functional consultants with Int4 Suite agents:

  • Test cycles shorten dramatically.
  • Reliance on external partners and scarce integration resources drops.
  • Confidence in end-to-end quality rises.

This isn’t about replacing automation experts or integration teams. It’s about enabling functional consultants to independently confirm that what leaves SAP (or comes into it) is still what the outside world expects.

It’s the missing puzzle piece for smooth, low-friction testing of integrated business processes in SAP transformations.

More information: 

Agentic AI Testing for Greenfield S/4HANA Outbound Interfaces - Part 1
Int4 Suite — your SAP Joule testbed and skills builder
Process-Aware Agentic Testing of SAP with Int4 Suite
Agentic Testing and Simulation with Int4 Suite's SAP Business Knowledge Graph

entry.title: SAP Integration Suite - Content Modifier
entry.content:
Content Modifier

Content Modifier is a tool used in integration processes to adjust incoming messages by modifying headers, properties, or the message body to meet specific requirements.

Content Modifier has 4 types:

  1. General.
  2. Message Header.
  3. Exchange Property.
  4. Message Body.

General:

In General We can change the Content Modifier Name as you want.

 

Message Header:

These carry metadata about the message, such as content type or routing information.

Note: Metadata refers to information about the message itself, not the content of the message.

 

Exchange Property:

Exchange Property is a key/value pair used to store data temporarily during message processing. It's a powerful and flexible way to pass information between steps in an integration flow. 

 

Message Body:

In message body there are:

  1. Type – In type there are two types Constant - for fixed body & Expression - for Custom/Expression Language body.
  2. Body – We can call the headers & Properties which were created in the before fields and we can enter the custom body.

 

In Content Modifier, we can define values with source types according to requirement:

Constant:

  • To set a fixed value, Best for static data that doesn't change.
  • Example: Country = India

Expression:

  • Dynamic values, Allows you to use simple Expression Language.
  • Syntax: ${header.<name>}, ${property.<name>}

Global Variable:

  • Refers to values defined as Global Variables in the CPI runtime.
  • Used in more complex scenarios and reusable scripts.
  • When you define global settings used across many flows.

Header:

  • Gets the value from an existing message header.
  • Example: You may copy a header like Authorization into a new one.
  • When values are already present in headers and you want to reuse or forward them.

Local Variable:

  • Used for values created temporarily during the flow (like in scripts).
  • Best for temporary or calculated values.

Number Range:

  • Auto-generates a number from a configured number range.
  • Can be used to generate sequential IDs.

Property:

  • Gets the value from a message property (set in Content Modifier or other steps).
  • Example: Set city as a property earlier, then reuse it here.
  • Properties are used for temporary storage during flow execution.

XPath: Extracts data from the XML message body using an XPath expression.

  • Example: /root/customer/city

 

 

Content Modifier Example:

  • In Message Header - City Name added with value of Guntur with Constant type.

  • In Exchange Property – timestamp as Name with Expression Source type & Source Value is ${date:now:yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss}

  • In Message body we called the names added in Header & Property.

Output:

Time & Address are printed in the output body as shown in above image.

 

 

SAP Integration Suite  #Content Modifier #Message Header #Exchange Property

entry.title: Extensibility in the Age of AI: Why ABCD Is Easier (and Smarter) Than You Think
entry.content:
The CTO’s Concern

Not long ago, during a client conversation, a CTO expressed a concern that resonated deeply:

“We need to extend our system. But every time someone says ‘let’s customize this,’ I feel we’re piling risk. And now with AI coming, I’m afraid our mess gets worse.”

That statement captures the heart of a challenge many SAP customers face. Customization has been both the strength and the Achilles’ heel of enterprise landscapes. It allows us to adapt, innovate, and differentiate — but it often comes with technical debt, upgrade pain, and hidden complexity.

Why Extensibility Matters More in the AI Era

Let’s pause here. Ten years ago, if you added a Z-table or tweaked a user exit, the worst-case scenario was some testing pain during an upgrade. Today?

  • If your data model is inconsistent, your AI forecasts won’t align with reality.
  • If your logic is buried in old exits, Joule copilots can’t “see” your processes.
  • If your core is brittle, cloud updates feel like risks, not opportunities.

In other words: extensibility is no longer just about “making it work.” It’s about making AI possible.

And now, with SAP’s AI ambitions accelerating — embedded copilots, Joule agents, and business data clouds powering predictive intelligence — the messy customizations of the past risk becoming blockers for the future.

This is where ABCD extensibility comes in. Far from being abstract jargon, it’s a practical compass to guide enterprises on how to extend the system smartly, safely, and in a way that enables AI instead of hindering it.

The ABCD Levels: A Human Explanation

SAP’s ABCD framework doesn’t exist to confuse us — it exists to help customers navigate the grey space between innovation and stability.

Here’s the official breakdown, with real-world translation:

A Short Story: The MV45AFZZ Debate

Anyone who has worked in SAP Sales and Distribution knows the legendary include MV45AFZZ. For decades, it’s been the go-to spot for developers to implement custom sales order checks, validations, and logic.

At one client, a senior developer proudly said, “We’ve been using MV45AFZZ for 15 years, and it works just fine. Why change?”

And he wasn’t wrong. In many ways, that’s a Level B extensibility choice: small, controlled, and serving the business well. (In fact, SAP even documented this in SAP Note 3578329, proving that not all ‘old-school’ practices are bad.)

The problem comes when dozens of such exits pile up, undocumented, with overlapping logic — and suddenly the system feels like a house of cards.

Here’s the twist: ABCD extensibility is not about banning MV45AFZZ or exits. It’s about putting them in the right place, with the right intent.

The IDoc Question: Clean or Not?

One of the most common debates I hear is: “We use IDocs everywhere. Are they clean core?”

The answer: Yes, IDocs are safe — they fall under Level B.

SAP clarified this in the IDoc Clean Core blog.

Why? Because IDocs are:

  • Officially documented.
  • Supported by SAP.
  • Used for integration and still relevant in S/4HANA.

That said, if you’re starting a greenfield cloud project, you may want to move toward APIs and Event Mesh (Level A) instead. But if you’ve got an existing landscape with IDocs, don’t panic — they’re not “unclean.”

Real-World Scenarios: Which Level to Choose?

Why This Matters for AI

AI copilots like Joule don’t “guess.” They rely on:

  • Stable APIs (Level A).
  • Clear data models (A & B).
  • Trusted logic (not buried in Level C/D).

If your system is full of Level D hacks, AI copilots won’t understand your processes. But if you steer toward A and B (with C monitored), you create an AI-ready enterprise.

 Closing Thought

Extensibility is not the villain. Misuse is.

The ABCD framework gives us a shared language:

  • A when we want innovation + AI without worry.
  • B when proven frameworks like IDocs or MV45AFZZ still serve us.
  • C only if there’s no choice — and we track it closely.
  • D only if we want to leave a headache for the next generation.

So next time someone says “let’s customize,” you don’t need to panic. You just need to ask:

Is this A, B, C, or D? And that one question can mean the difference between a system that blocks AI — and one that accelerates it.

#SAPCleanCore #SAPExtensibility #ABAPCloud #SAPAI #SAPBTP #S4HANACloud #IDoc

entry.title: Joule Studio Hands-on October 16th 2025 @ ASUG-WI in Madison Wisconsin
entry.content:
Join us on October 16th in beautiful Madison, Wisconsin for the next ASUG-Wisconsin chapter meeting. 

The meeting will be held on the University of Wisconsin - Madison campus at the Pyle Center right in the heart of campus with a fantastic view of Lake Mendota. 

We have a great agenda planned and for those of you looking to get your hands-on Joule Studio in SAP Build then this is the event for you.  We will have a 3-hr hands-on session as part of this event along with a great session about Madison-based company Accuray and their journey from Microsoft Dynamics ERP to SAP S/4HANA including their use of SAP Business Technology Platform and SAP Integration Suite.

Be sure to Register NOW as there will be limited seating for the hands-on session.  

The 3-hour hands-on session will explore how Joule Studio enables developers and technical professionals to design, build, and deploy intelligent AI skills and agents within SAP’s ecosystem.

Why Joule Studio?
Learn the purpose and value of Joule Studio as part of SAP’s broader AI framework. Understand how it connects data, applications, and processes to deliver intelligent, context-aware solutions.

What You Can Build
Discover the wide range of possibilities with Joule Studio—from automating workflows and enhancing business operations to building conversational assistants that support real-time decision-making.

Let’s Build a Joule Skill (Hands-On)
Follow a guided, step-by-step exercise to create your first Joule skill. Learn how to define inputs, design logic, and test your skill in the Joule Studio environment.

Art of Creating Your Own Agents
Dive deeper into the process of designing, configuring, and orchestrating agents. Understand best practices for managing agent behaviors, optimizing performance, and ensuring seamless collaboration between skills.

Illustrative Use Cases
See how organizations are applying Joule Studio in real scenarios—from HR virtual assistants and procurement insights to IT automation and operational analytics.

Resources and Next Steps
Wrap up with guidance on additional enablement materials, documentation, and community resources to help you continue developing with Joule Studio.

Join Global VP Lester Lobo and Rugved Chavan, Data Engineering and AI Specialist, as they lead us through this hands-on session.  

Register Now to join us in Madison on October 16th!

entry.title: What's New in SAP BTP - Q3 2025
entry.content:
This third quarter brought some helpful innovation highlights for SAP Business Technology Platform, that we’re excited to share with you! The Q3 Innobytes demonstrate the progress we made in SAP BTP over the last months. Check out the video below and explore the latest features in Application Development, Joule and more. Enjoy watching!

 

App Dev Highlights

AI-powered Capabilities in SAP Build Work Zone

In the first demo, three new AI capabilities in SAP Build Work Zone are demonstrated to help you work smarter and more efficiently.

With AI Summarization, you can create a concise summary of long documents within seconds. Simply find the content in your workspace and click Summarize to save time and work smarter.

To make engaging with content easier, you can access AI Comment Generation via the AI icon to generate contextual comments, helping respond quickly and intelligently. 

To support content creation, the AI Text Generation helps with drafting an introduction or brainstorming ideas. In the workspace editor, you can ask AI to generate Text and let it support your experience in the SAP Build Work Zone.  

Watch the demo starting at 00:09 to see these innovations in action.

Learn more

  • Blog Post SAP Build Work Zone
  • SAP Build Work Zone
  •  SAP Community

 

Skill Builder in Joule General Availability

Welcome to Joule Studio, a powerful tool that enables you to create intelligent AI agents and custom-built Joule Skills based on your specific business needs.

The creation of Joule Studio’s AI agent is seamlessly integrated with SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP), leveraging its robust security, scalability, and connectivity to SAP systems for maximum efficiency. In this demo, a new Joule Skill is created that automates the workflow of the badge printing process. It automatically generates and prints employee badges by integrating Joule Studio with the SAP HR database, and everything you need for this process is in one place.

Start the demo at 01:51 to get more insights.

Learn more

  • Get Started with Joule Studio
  • Detailed Tutorial
  • SAP Community Blog Page

 

Downtime-Optimized Upgrades for SAP BTP ABAP Environment

SAP BTP ABAP Environment now uses blue-green-fashioned lifecycle management to minimize the downtime during hotfixes and version upgrades.

A recent update demonstrates that switching to a new runtime takes only seconds, with release upgrades targeting about 30 minutes. This innovation aims to make the process more transparent, aligning with downtime more efficiently. With this improvement, we are minimizing downtime and optimizing upgrades! 

This demo uses an example to highlight this innovation further (starting at 03:15).

Learn more

  • SAP BTP ABAP Environment – Maintenance Windows and Major Upgrade Windows in 2025

 

Integration

AI Adapter in SAP Integration Suite

In August, we released an AI adapter for Cloud Integration capability of the SAP Integration Suite on the SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP).

Available as part of the Standard plan and above, it allows integration flows to interact with Large Language Models, adding AI directly into the integration at runtime. In this demo iflow, a product review is analyzed with OpenAI to enrich them with customer sentiment. This example shows the detection of a negative sentiment in a product review through GPT-5. The adapter is available now for you to try.

Watch this part (starting at 04:29) to get more insights.

Learn more

  • AI Adapter Blog Post
  • AI Adapter on SAP Business Accelerator Hub

 

Data & Analytics

SQL Generation for SAP HANA in Joule

In SAP Build Code, Joule can now automatically generate SAP HANA SQL based on natural language prompts.

You can either execute it directly within the Joule panel or you can copy the SQL command into the SQL Console to perform additional operations or refinements. This integration streamlines workflows, boosts productivity, and reduces errors, eliminating manual coding and tool switching.

This is how it’s done:

  1. Enable SQL generation using object definitions in your workspace’s settings
  2. Navigate to your Joule extension and select the command type HANA SQL
  3. Type your Natural Language Prompt – Joule will then generate and execute the SQL for you
  4. Execute or add operations or refinements to the results

See these steps in action (starting at 05:57).

Learn more

  • Generate SQL from Natural Language using Joule

 

Cross

Modifiable Transport Requests

SAP Cloud Transport Management Service now supports Modifiable Transport Requests, allowing you to test and adjust transport requests in safe test nodes before releasing them to production.

This is how it works:

  1. Create a Modifiable Transport Request with the Create button.
  2. When opening the request, see the Tracking tab that shows the transport landscape and is now open for changes.
  3. Add content to the request and click the Test button to import directly or later and freely add or remove content.
  4. Release the request when testing is completed.

This flexible approach enables adding, removing, or redeploying content as needed, ensuring higher quality and safer deployments. Automation and Integration with other SAP BTP services are planned, so stay tuned for more to come.

To see this demo in action, watch the video (starting at 07:36).

Learn more

  • Modifiable Transport Request Blog Post

 

Cross (Cloud ALM)

Change Point Detection for Custom BTP Apps in SAP Cloud ALM

Running custom apps on SAP BTP embraces Cloud Flexibility with the Clean Core Principle. With the SAP Cloud ALM for Operations, you can monitor SAP and non-SAP applications end-to-end. This feature ensures business continuity and operational efficiency.

Real User Monitoring gives you clear insights into usage by tracking executions, performance, and response times all in one interface. 

If the performance suddenly shifts, Change Point Detection identifies unusual patterns in the performance compared to historical trends. You can then directly navigate to the respective request and even receive alerts or emails when a change point is detected. This helps quick investigation of the issue and ensures smooth operations.

This new feature is highlighted (starting at 08:52).

Learn more

  • SAP Cloud ALM for Operations Expert Portal
  • SAP BTP Developer’s Guide (Github)
  • Join us for TechEd:
  • CS101 | Discover SAP Cloud ALM for operations in action
  • CS261 | Monitoring a custom SAP BTP application with SAP Cloud ALM for operations

 

Share your thoughts 

These videos are for YOU, and we would love to hear your impressions. How do you like the video? How can we improve the upcoming videos? Please share your feedback by liking this post or leaving a comment below.

Thank you for your support and happy viewing, sharing, and enjoying!

You Might Also Be Interested In

  • SAP BTP Garage: monthly LIVE webinar with hands-on use case walkthroughs and demos.
  • Unlocking SAP BTP: monthly podcast covering all things SAP BTP.

entry.title: SAP Integration Suite - Operations - Landscape
entry.content:
Dear Community,

this blog provides practical insights into setting up a proper landscape for SAP Integration Suite.

Intention:

With the move to Integration Suite as middleware, customers will reach an early point at which they need to consider their future landscape setup. SAP provides many resources (such as the Reference Architecture, Discovery Center, Naming Conventions, Learning Journey, Considerations on the System Landscape for Integration when On-boarding into SAP Cloud Integration) to help them get started and become familiar with the new environment. Based on multiple customer ramp-ups, a clear picture is emerging of what a solid setup can look like.

Approach:

We collect the basic information required to run and operate Integration Suite properly. This includes a simple consideration of the account setup and the services we recommend for your integration landscape (such as Transport Management, SAP Cloud ALM, etc.).

Solution:

How many tenants (SAP BTP subaccounts) are needed for SAP Integration Suite to support such a landscape?

"A general rule of thumb is to align the landscape of the SAP Integration Suite with the primary business system in your architecture."

However, the decision between a 2-tier or 3-tier landscape for SAP Integration Suite also depends on various organizational and functional factors:

  • A 2-tier landscape is suitable for simpler scenarios where mostly preconfigured content is used.
  • A 3-tier landscape is suitable for more complex environments with existing multi-tier on-premise systems and extended quality assurance requirements.

What about the sizing of Integration Suite in comparison to PI/PO?

As of now, the number of messages is the primary factor influencing cost. Other aspects — such as sizing — do not affect the price. Scaling is handled entirely by SAP, and there are predefined internal value sets. SAP Cloud Integration generally scales well (scale up/out), provided that the integration flows are designed according to the design guidelines.

For Edge Integration Cell, the concept is different, as the infrastructure is managed within the customer's private landscape. Therefore, planned sizing should be taken into consideration.

Are there differences between DEV, Test, and Prod regarding message calculation? What should we take into consideration?

SAP Integration Suite - Message Metric Definition serves as our source of truth for message calculation in SAP Integration Suite. It also includes the following important information: “There is no concept of development, test, and production landscapes in SAP Integration Suite. Messages on all tenants are metered based on the description in this note.”

What do we need to start with our Integration Suite setup? 

As a very basic setup, we would take the Integration Suite subscription into consideration. This means, according to question 1, we are going to deploy and roll out our landscape according to our needs. The naming of directories is flexible and can be changed afterwards. Due to this fact, in our consideration we will name the base directory Development, Test, and Production, everything else is flexibel to your customer needs. 

Architectural Overview BTP

 

General Naming - Stage Development

DirectoryDevelopment
SubaccountDev – SAP Integration Suite
Subdomaincompany-dev-sap-integration-suite-uniqueid or dev-sap-integration-suite-uniqueid
Cloud Foundry Orgdev-sap-integration-suite
Spacedev-sap-integration-suite

General Naming - Stage Test

DirectoryTest
SubaccountTest - SAP Integration Suite
Subdomaincompany-test-sap-integration-suite or test-sap-integration-suite
Cloud Foundry Orgtest-sap-integration-suite
Spacetest-sap-integration-suite

General Naming - Stage Prod

DirectoryProduction
SubaccountProd - SAP Integration Suite
Subdomaincompany-prod-sap-integration-suite-uniqueid or prod-sap-integration-suite-uniqueid
Cloud Foundry Orgprod-sap-integration-suite
Spaceprod-sap-integration-suite

Is there anything else we need to take into consideration?

Beyond the Integration Suite we recommend to take the following further Services also in consideation:

By default, you can leverage SAP's default Identity Provider (IDP) for user access and role management. Users who should work in the Integration Suite environment can be assigned predefined roles. This falls under Identity and User Management.

SAP Cloud Transport Management can be used for your basic landscape and transport scenarios in Integration Suite. Besides a file-based manual approach, you can transport your content across the landscape in a more structured way using Cloud Transport Management.

Important: If you want to leverage Cloud Transport Management in combination with Cloud ALM, the Cloud Transport Management service should not be set up within the same account as Cloud ALM. Follow the Guideline: Setup and Administration for SAP Cloud ALM.

SAP Cloud ALM helps you to implement and operate intelligent cloud and hybrid business solutions. With the Integration and Exception Monitoring for the Cloud Integration part of Integration Suite, you can already cover a comprehensive monitoring concept for your hybrid integration landscape with minimal effort. Since Cloud ALM is basically free for customers, it should be one of your key considerations.

CI/CD concept for Integration Suite.

To set up a proper CI/CD pipeline for automated transports, Integration Suite provides Management APIs, which can be leveraged in third-party solutions.

Additionally, our SAP partners offer dedicated automation tools specifically designed for Integration Suite. Check out the SAP Store to get the latest information and products, including those provided by our partners.

Besides partner solutions, there are also some open-source approaches.

Parallel development of integration flows as part of a CI/CD concept - How do we handle this? 

From a general approach, a single integration flow should be handled by one developer.

Additionally, there are many other solution approaches available, such as partner solutions (see SAP Store ) and design approaches. An individual cross-check with your implementation partner is recommended to identify the best concept for your environment.

We want to use AI features?

Check out SAP Discover Center for Integration Suite and 2903776 - SAP Integration Suite – Service Plans and Upgrade Paths with the Premium Account, AI features will be available. Take into consideration that, as of now, the Premium Service Plan is subscription-based. For more information about the connect with your SAP Account Team to find the right plan for your needs.

As of now, generative AI options are only available for specific regions. See: 3515787 - Generative AI features 

---

We’d love to hear your thoughts and experiences with SAP Integration Suite. What challenges are you facing? How can we help you unlock the full potential of your IT ecosystem? Feel free to reach out to us via SAP Integration Services.

#Modernize #Integrate #Innovate – SAP Integration Modernization TEAM

entry.title: Test Automation Solution for PO7.5 to SAP Integration Suite Migration
entry.content:
Test Automation Solution for PO 7.5 to SAP Integration Suite Migration

Enterprises are transitioning away from legacy SAP Process Orchestration (PO) towards SAP Integration Suite as PO approaches end of life. While this migration promises better scalability and integration capabilities, it also brings a significant challenge of ensuring data consistency and integrity throughout the process without disrupting business users.

In any migration project, testing can consume around 40% to 50% of the overall effort if done manually. Manual testing is time-consuming and prone to human error. Complex interfaces, multiple test cases, and large volumes of data drives up the time and cost of testing. Thoroughly validating that the new environment behaves as expected is critical to a successful transition. This is where automated testing solutions comes into play, simplifying and accelerating the validation of migrated interfaces.

 We have built a test tool to extract, compare, and validate payloads between your legacy PO system and SAP Integration Suite. This tool simplifies and automates testing of migrated iFlows, making your transition smoother, faster, and more reliable.

Key Features of Our Test Automation Tool

  • Automates payload extraction from SAP PO 7.5: Extracts input and output messages from your existing PO environment. It establishes connectivity with the PO System and pulls the payload for testing.
  • Validates test cases directly against migrated flows in Cloud Integration : Run test scenarios on the target platform(SAP Integration Suite) to verify correctness of migration.
  • Compares output payloads across systems: Detect any mismatches or errors.
  • Supports various testing approach: Whether testing single or multiple interfaces, Our tool adapts to project needs. It supports regression testing.
  • Generates detailed, downloadable test reports: Gain visibility into test results with comprehensive  reports.
  • Alerts via mails in case of failures: Immediate notifications enable quick corrective actions.
  • Supports standard adapters.
  • Monitoring through quality management and governance dashboard.

Whether you are migrating a few interfaces or hundreds, test tool brings efficiency, visibility, and reliability to your testing process saving both time and cost.

Integrating our test automation tool into your migration strategy will help with:

  • Faster testing cycles that reduce the overall migration timeline.
  • Improved reliability with consistent, repeatable automated test runs.
  • Greater visibility into testing outcomes through detailed reports.
  • Enhanced confidence that migrated interfaces behave exactly as expected.
  • Scalability to handle migrations involving just a few interfaces or hundreds.

Ready to accelerate your PO migration testing during migration? Reach out to learn how our tool can simplify your migration from PI/PO to SAP Integration Suite and save time, reduce costs, and ensure a smooth migration.
